5-14.description: The protagonist writes a letter to Mrs. Saville, expressing his feelings and experiences as he begins his adventurous journey from St. Petersburgh, describing the cold breeze and his vivid daydreams about the icy regions he plans to explore.
5-14.location: St. Petersburgh, a room or study
text_phrases: St. Petersburgh, Dec. 11th, 17—
cold northern breeze play upon my cheeks
my daydreams become more fervent and vivid
the pole is the seat of frost and desolation
the region of beauty and delight
the sun is for ever visible
broad disk just skirting the horizon
perpetual splendour

5-14.description: The protagonist reflects on his past experiences and preparations for his current expedition, including his time spent with whale-fishers and studying various subjects to equip himself for the journey.
text_phrases: I accompanied the whale-fishers
endured cold, famine, thirst, and want of sleep
worked harder than the common sailors
devoted my nights to the study of mathematics, the theory of medicine, and physical science
hired myself as an under-mate in a Greenland whaler

5-14.description: The protagonist describes the experience of traveling in Russia during winter, highlighting the pleasant motion of sledges over snow and the necessity of wearing furs to combat the cold.
5-14.location: Snowy landscape between St. Petersburgh and Archangel
text_phrases: the most favourable period for travelling in Russia
fly quickly over the snow in their sledges
the motion is pleasant
wrapped in furs
remaining seated motionless for hours

15-24.description: R. Walton writes to his sister about his preparations in Archangel, hiring a vessel, and gathering a crew for his upcoming expedition.
text_phrases: How slowly the time passes here, encompassed as I am by frost and snow!
I have hired a vessel and am occupied in collecting my sailors

15-24.description: R. Walton expresses his feelings of loneliness and desire for a friend who can share and understand his ambitions and struggles.
text_phrases: I have no friend, Margaret: when I am glowing with the enthusiasm of success, there will be none to participate my joy
I desire the company of a man who could sympathise with me, whose eyes would reply to mine

15-24.description: R. Walton recounts the story of the master of the ship, a man known for his kindness and integrity, and his romantic past involving a young Russian lady.
text_phrases: The master is a person of an excellent disposition and is remarkable in the ship for his gentleness and the mildness of his discipline
Some years ago he loved a young Russian lady of moderate fortune

25-44.scene_title: Robert Walton's Letter to Mrs. Saville
25-44.description: Robert Walton writes to his sister expressing his thoughts and feelings about his upcoming voyage, his attachment to the sea, and his concerns for safety.
text_phrases: I am going to unexplored regions
the land of mist and snow
I shall kill no albatross
my passionate enthusiasm for the dangerous mysteries of ocean

25-44.description: Robert Walton's ship is nearly surrounded by ice, creating a dangerous situation, when a mysterious sledge drawn by dogs and guided by a gigantic figure is spotted.
text_phrases: nearly surrounded by ice
a very thick fog
vast and irregular plains of ice
a low carriage, fixed on a sledge and drawn by dogs
a being which had the shape of a man, but apparently of gigantic stature

45-61.description: A European man is found on a sledge drifting on a large ice fragment. He is persuaded to board the ship for his safety.
text_phrases: sledge, like that we had seen before
drifted towards us in the night on a large fragment of ice
Only one dog remained alive
sailors were persuading to enter the vessel
wrapped him up in blankets
near the chimney of the kitchen stove

45-61.description: The rescued man is initially taken to the cabin but faints due to the lack of fresh air, so he is brought back to the deck and revived.
text_phrases: carried him into the cabin
quitted the fresh air he fainted
brought him back to the deck
restored him to animation by rubbing him with brandy
ate a little soup

45-61.description: The stranger inquires about the fate of another sledge and reflects on his own journey, showing signs of deep emotional turmoil.
text_phrases: inquired if I thought that the breaking up of the ice had destroyed the other sledge
new spirit of life animated the decaying frame of the stranger
persuaded him to remain in the cabin
watch for the sledge which had before appeared

62-74.description: The narrator describes his growing affection and admiration for the stranger aboard the ship. They engage in deep conversations about their lives and ambitions.
text_phrases: I shall continue my journal concerning the stranger
He is now much recovered from his illness and is continually on the deck
watching for the sledge that preceded his own

62-74.description: The stranger, overwhelmed by emotion during a conversation, covers his face and sheds tears, revealing the depth of his despair to the narrator.
text_phrases: a dark gloom spread over my listener’s countenance
he placed his hands before his eyes
tears trickle fast from between his fingers
a groan burst from his heaving breast

62-74.description: After conquering his emotions, the stranger discusses personal matters with the narrator, expressing a calm, settled grief.
text_phrases: Having conquered the violence of his feelings
he appeared to despise himself for being the slave of passion
his countenance became expressive of a calm, settled grief

62-74.description: The stranger shares his past misfortunes and warns the narrator about the dangers of pursuing knowledge, hinting at his own tragic experiences.
text_phrases: You may easily perceive, Captain Walton, that I have suffered great and unparalleled misfortunes
You seek for knowledge and wisdom, as I once did
Prepare to hear of occurrences which are usually deemed marvellous

75-83.description: The narrator expresses eagerness to hear the promised narrative of his companion, who is resigned to his fate but willing to share his story.
75-83.location: A room where the narrator and his companion are conversing
text_phrases: I was much gratified by the offered communication
he should renew his grief by a recital of his misfortunes
I felt the greatest eagerness to hear the promised narrative
my fate is nearly fulfilled
listen to my history

75-83.description: The narrator's father discovers the abode of his friend Beaufort, who has fallen into poverty, and visits him in a state of misery and despair.
text_phrases: my father discovered his abode
hastened to the house
misery and despair alone welcomed him
Beaufort had saved but a very small sum of money
he lay on a bed of sickness

75-83.description: Caroline Beaufort, after her father's death, is left in poverty and struggles to support herself through various means.
text_phrases: Caroline Beaufort possessed a mind of an uncommon mould
she procured plain work; she plaited straw
earn a pittance scarcely sufficient to support life

84-89.description: The scene depicts the moment when the protagonist's mother, accompanied by the protagonist, visits a poor cottage on the shores of Lake Como, where they encounter a peasant family and a distinct, fair-haired child.
84-89.location: Shores of Lake Como, near a peasant's cottage
text_phrases: excursion beyond the frontiers of Italy
shores of the Lake of Como
cottages of the poor
poor cot in the foldings of a vale
half-clothed children
peasant and his wife
scanty meal to five hungry babes
child was thin and very fair
brightest living gold hair
poverty of her clothing

84-89.description: This scene illustrates the moment when Elizabeth, the fair-haired child, first arrives at the protagonist's villa and is introduced as a new member of the family.
text_phrases: father returned from Milan
playing with me in the hall of our villa
child fairer than pictured cherub
radiance from her looks
lighter than the chamois of the hills

90-96.description: The scene depicts the family's home in Geneva and their campagne on Belrive, focusing on the serene and secluded life led by the narrator's family. It highlights the narrator's childhood filled with love, learning, and the influence of his friend Henry Clerval.
text_phrases: We possessed a house in Geneva, and a campagne on Belrive
the lives of my parents were passed in considerable seclusion
Henry Clerval was the son of a merchant of Geneva
He loved enterprise, hardship, and even danger for its own sake
Elizabeth shone like a shrine-dedicated lamp in our peaceful home

90-96.description: The scene captures the moment the narrator discovers Cornelius Agrippa's works in an inn during a family trip, leading to a pivotal shift in his interests towards the secrets of natural philosophy.
text_phrases: we all went on a party of pleasure to the baths near Thonon
the inclemency of the weather obliged us to remain a day confined to the inn
I chanced to find a volume of the works of Cornelius Agrippa
My father looked carelessly at the title page of my book

97-105.description: Victor returns home and immerses himself in the works of ancient philosophers, seeking the secrets of nature.
text_phrases: returned home
procure the whole works of this author
read and studied the wild fancies of these writers with delight

97-105.description: A violent thunderstorm hits near Victor's house at Belrive, leading to the destruction of an old oak tree by a lightning strike.
characters: man of great research in natural philosophy
text_phrases: violent and terrible thunderstorm
stream of fire issue from an old and beautiful oak
oak had disappeared, and nothing remained but a blasted stump

97-105.description: After the thunderstorm and discussions on electricity, Victor shifts his academic focus from natural philosophy to mathematics.
text_phrases: gave up my former occupations
betook myself to the mathematics
branches of study appertaining to that science

106-112.description: Elizabeth suffers from scarlet fever, and despite initial hesitations, her mother attends to her, ultimately saving Elizabeth but contracting the illness herself which leads to her death.
text_phrases: Elizabeth had caught the scarlet fever
her illness was severe
she attended her sickbed
her watchful attentions triumphed over the malignity of the distemper

106-112.description: On her deathbed, the mother speaks to Elizabeth and the narrator, expressing her hopes for their future and resigning herself to death.
text_phrases: On her deathbed
She joined the hands of Elizabeth and myself
I will endeavour to resign myself cheerfully to death

106-112.description: The narrator departs for Ingolstadt, saying farewell to his family and friends, reflecting on his life and the journey ahead.
text_phrases: Clerval spent the last evening with us
I descended to the carriage which was to convey me away
I threw myself into the chaise

113-121.description: The protagonist arrives in Ingolstadt, views the high white steeple of the town, and is conducted to his solitary apartment.
text_phrases: high white steeple of the town
conducted to my solitary apartment

113-121.description: The protagonist meets Professor Krempe, who criticizes his study of alchemy and advises him to start anew with modern natural philosophy.
text_phrases: M. Krempe, professor of natural philosophy
uncouth man
asked me several questions
mentioned the names of my alchemists
wrote down a list of several books

113-121.description: The protagonist attends a lecture by Professor Waldman, who praises modern chemistry and its achievements, contrasting it with ancient practices.
text_phrases: Professor Waldman entered
began his lecture by a recapitulation of the history of chemistry
pronouncing with fervour the names of the most distinguished discoverers
made a few preparatory experiments
panegyric upon modern chemistry

122-129.description: The protagonist visits M. Waldman at his home, where they discuss the protagonist's past studies and future in chemistry. M. Waldman offers guidance and access to his laboratory and books.
text_phrases: I paid M. Waldman a visit
His manners in private were even more mild and attractive
in his own house
He heard with attention
He then took me into his laboratory
explained to me the uses of his various machines
gave me the list of books

122-129.description: The protagonist becomes deeply engaged in chemical studies and laboratory work, making significant progress and discoveries.
text_phrases: my sole occupation
I read with ardour
I attended the lectures
in my laboratory
the stars often disappeared in the light of morning
my progress was rapid
made some discoveries in the improvement of some chemical instruments

122-129.description: Driven by curiosity about the principle of life, the protagonist delves into anatomy and spends time in vaults and charnel-houses studying decay and death.
text_phrases: the structure of the human frame
the science of anatomy
natural decay and corruption of the human body
spend days and nights in vaults and charnel-houses
the corruption of death succeed to the blooming cheek of life

130-136.description: The protagonist reflects on the overwhelming discovery he has made about life and death, feeling a mix of astonishment, delight, and rapture.
text_phrases: a sudden light broke in upon me
dizzy with the immensity of the prospect
astonishment which I had at first experienced
delight and rapture

130-136.description: The protagonist works tirelessly in his secret laboratory, using materials from charnel-houses and slaughter-houses to animate lifeless matter.
text_phrases: my workshop of filthy creation
the dissecting room and the slaughter-house furnished many of my materials
my human nature turn with loathing from my occupation
brought my work near to a conclusion

137-144.description: The protagonist works tirelessly in his lab, surrounded by the instruments of life, to infuse life into the lifeless body he has constructed. It is a stormy night, and the culmination of his efforts is marked by the creature's first movements and the opening of its eyes.
text_phrases: dreary night of November
instruments of life around me
the lifeless thing that lay at my feet
rain pattered dismally against the panes
candle was nearly burnt out
dull yellow eye of the creature open

137-144.description: After creating the creature, the protagonist is filled with horror and disgust at the sight of his creation. He flees the lab and experiences a restless night filled with disturbing dreams and a haunting encounter with the creature.
text_phrases: rushed out of the room
traversing my bed-chamber
wild dreams
Elizabeth
corpse of my dead mother
wretch—the miserable monster
curtain of the bed
dim and yellow light of the moon

145-157.description: The protagonist spends a restless night in the courtyard of his house, tormented by the creation of a monstrous being.
145-157.location: Courtyard of the house in Ingolstadt
text_phrases: I took refuge in the courtyard belonging to the house which I inhabited
walking up and down in the greatest agitation
listening attentively, catching and fearing each sound

145-157.description: After a night of horror, the protagonist sees the dawn and decides to leave the courtyard.
text_phrases: Morning, dismal and wet, at length dawned
the porter opened the gates of the court
I issued into the streets

145-157.description: The protagonist unexpectedly meets his friend Henry Clerval, which brings him a moment of joy amidst his turmoil.
text_phrases: I came at length opposite to the inn
the Swiss diligence; it stopped just where I was standing
Henry Clerval, who, on seeing me, instantly sprung out

145-157.description: The protagonist, accompanied by Clerval, returns to his college, dreading the possibility that the creature might still be there.
text_phrases: I walked with a quick pace, and we soon arrived at my college
Entreating him to remain a few minutes at the bottom of the stairs
I threw the door forcibly open

158-174.description: Victor is in his room, showing signs of extreme agitation and distress in front of Clerval, who is trying to understand what is wrong.
text_phrases: ascended into my room
servant presently brought breakfast
jumped over the chairs
clapped my hands
laughed aloud
wildness in my eyes
loud, unrestrained, heartless laughter

158-174.description: Victor recounts his severe illness and the devoted care provided by Clerval during his recovery, reflecting on his convalescence and the change of seasons observed from his window.
text_phrases: nervous fever
Henry was my only nurse
fallen leaves had disappeared
young buds were shooting forth
divine spring
sentiments of joy and affection revive

158-174.description: Clerval comforts Victor, discussing his recovery and presenting a letter from Elizabeth, which brings news from home and expresses concern for Victor's health.
text_phrases: Clerval put the following letter into my hands
letter from my own Elizabeth
constant letters of dear kind Henry
you are getting better
return to us
friends who love you dearly

175-184.description: Elizabeth Lavenza writes a detailed letter to Victor, updating him about the family, Justine Moritz, and local gossip from Geneva.
text_phrases: Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children
The blue lake and snow-clad mountains
our placid home and our contented hearts
Justine Moritz entered our family
Madame Moritz, her mother, was a widow
Justine was the favourite of her father
Justine could dissipate it, for the same reason that Ariosto gives concerning the beauty of Angelica
my dearest aunt died
Justine was called home by her repentant mother
little darling William
Louisa Biron is his favourite, a pretty little girl of five years of age
the good people of Geneva
the pretty Miss Mansfield
Your favourite schoolfellow, Louis Manoir
Write, dearest Victor

175-184.description: Victor Frankenstein reads Elizabeth's letter and is moved to write back immediately, expressing his feelings and determination to relieve their anxiety.
text_phrases: Dear, dear Elizabeth!
I will write instantly and relieve them from the anxiety they must feel.
I wrote, and this exertion greatly fatigued me
my convalescence had commenced, and proceeded regularly
In another fortnight I was able to leave my chamber.

185-191.description: Victor Frankenstein introduces Henry Clerval to the professors at the university, where they discuss Victor's progress and change the subject to alleviate his discomfort.
text_phrases: introduce Clerval to the several professors
chemical instrument
my apparatus
changed my apartment
M. Waldman inflicted torture
praised with kindness and warmth
M. Krempe was not equally docile
harsh blunt encomiums

185-191.description: Victor and Henry enjoy a pedestrian tour around Ingolstadt, engaging with nature and reflecting on their past experiences and future plans.
text_phrases: pedestrian tour in the environs of Ingolstadt
salubrious air
natural incidents of our progress
conversation of my friend
aspect of nature
cheerful faces of children
serene sky and verdant fields
flowers of spring bloomed in the hedges

192-213.description: Henry tries to amuse Victor with tales and arguments as they return to their college, observing the joyous environment around them.
text_phrases: Henry rejoiced in my gaiety
he exerted himself to amuse me
the peasants were dancing
every one we met appeared gay and happy

192-213.description: Victor reads a letter from his father informing him of his brother William's murder, leading to a profound emotional reaction.
text_phrases: I found the following letter from my father
William is dead!—that sweet child, whose smiles delighted and warmed my heart, who was so gentle, yet so gay! Victor, he is murdered!
I threw the letter on the table, and covered my face with my hands

192-213.description: Victor's father, niece, and brothers search for William at dusk, eventually finding his lifeless body with signs of murder.
text_phrases: Last Thursday (May 7th), I, my niece, and your two brothers, went to walk in Plainpalais
it was already dusk
we discovered that William and Ernest, who had gone on before, were not to be found
we returned again, with torches
my lovely boy, whom the night before I had seen blooming and active in health, stretched on the grass livid and motionless

192-213.description: After reading the tragic news, Victor and Henry discuss the loss, with Henry expressing sympathy and Victor deciding to return to Geneva.
text_phrases: Clerval, who had watched my countenance as I read this letter, was surprised to observe the despair that succeeded the joy
Tears also gushed from the eyes of Clerval, as he read the account of my misfortune
To go instantly to Geneva: come with me, Henry, to order the horses

214-222.description: The protagonist, Clerval, speaks as they hurry through the streets, then the protagonist bids farewell to Clerval and begins a melancholic journey towards his native town, reflecting on the changes that might have occurred during his absence.
214-222.location: Streets leading to the outskirts of a town
text_phrases: Clerval spoke thus as we hurried through the streets
I hurried into a cabriolet
bade farewell to my friend

214-222.description: The protagonist spends two days in Lausanne in a state of emotional turmoil, contemplating the calm scenery of the lake and mountains which gradually restores his peace.
text_phrases: remained two days at Lausanne
contemplated the lake
the waters were placid
snowy mountains, 'the palaces of nature'

214-222.description: During a stormy night, the protagonist crosses a lake by boat to visit the place where his brother was murdered, encountering a terrifying storm and eventually spotting the monstrous figure he created.
text_phrases: cross the lake in a boat
lightning playing on the summit of Mont Blanc
thunder burst with a terrific crash
a figure which stole from behind a clump of trees
a flash of lightning illuminated the object

223-234.scene_title: Victor's Tormented Reflections in the Rain
223-234.description: Victor stands alone in the darkness, enveloped by the pouring rain, reflecting on the monstrous deeds of the creature he created.
text_phrases: I remained motionless
the rain still continued
enveloped in an impenetrable darkness

223-234.scene_title: Victor's Arrival at His Father's House
223-234.description: Victor enters his father's house early in the morning, trying not to disturb the family, and reflects on the memories of his mother and brother.
text_phrases: I entered my father’s house
I went into the library
picture of my mother, which stood over the mantel-piece
miniature of William

223-234.description: Ernest welcomes Victor back home, sharing the grief of recent family tragedies and discussing the accusations against Justine Moritz.
text_phrases: Ernest entered
Tears, unrestrained, fell from my brother’s eyes
Justine Moritz, who was so amiable

235-247.description: Victor passionately asserts Justine's innocence to his father and Ernest, despite the prevailing belief of her guilt in the murder of young William.
text_phrases: You are all mistaken; I know the murderer.
Justine, poor, good Justine, is innocent.
my father entered
unhappiness deeply impressed on his countenance

235-247.description: Elizabeth expresses her hope and despair regarding Justine's innocence and the upcoming trial, showing deep emotional conflict and support for Justine.
text_phrases: Your arrival, my dear cousin, fills me with hope.
You perhaps will find some means to justify my poor guiltless Justine.
If she is condemned, I never shall know joy more.

235-247.description: Justine stands trial, maintaining her composure despite the overwhelming public opinion against her. The tension in the courtroom is palpable as evidence is presented.
text_phrases: The appearance of Justine was calm.
She was dressed in mourning.
the advocate against her had stated the charge
several witnesses were called

248-256.description: Justine stands in a courtroom, defending herself against the accusation of murder. She is visibly distressed but speaks with determination about her innocence and recounts her whereabouts on the night of the murder.
text_phrases: Justine was called on for her defence
her countenance had altered
she collected her powers and spoke
I rest my innocence on a plain and simple explanation
the permission of Elizabeth
the house of an aunt at Chêne
the gates of Geneva were shut
spent several hours of the night in a barn
It was dawn and she quitted her asylum

248-256.description: Elizabeth, amidst a courtroom setting, passionately defends Justine, describing her character and their close relationship, attempting to sway the judges and the public.
text_phrases: Elizabeth saw even this last resource
I am the cousin of the unhappy child who was murdered
I wish to be allowed to speak
She nursed Madame Frankenstein
She was warmly attached to the child who is now dead
notwithstanding all the evidence produced against her, I believe and rely on her perfect innocence

248-256.description: The courtroom scene where the verdict against Justine is delivered. The atmosphere is tense and somber as the ballots are revealed to be all black, condemning Justine.
text_phrases: the ballots had been thrown; they were all black
Justine was condemned
my own agitation and anguish was extreme
the fangs of remorse tore my bosom

257-272.description: Victor and Elizabeth visit Justine in her gloomy prison chamber. Justine, manacled and despondent, confesses to a crime she claims she did not commit, only to have falsely confessed to gain absolution. The emotional turmoil is palpable as Elizabeth reassures her of her belief in Justine's innocence.
text_phrases: gloomy prison chamber
Justine sitting on some straw
her hands were manacled
head rested on her knees
Elizabeth eagerly demanded the result
Justine threw herself at the feet of Elizabeth, weeping bitterly

257-272.description: In the prison chamber, Justine pleads her innocence to Elizabeth and Victor, expressing her despair and resignation to her fate. Elizabeth vows to fight for Justine's innocence, deeply moved and determined.
text_phrases: Justine rose on seeing us enter
Justine threw herself at the feet of Elizabeth, weeping bitterly
Elizabeth, 'I will go, although she is guilty'
Justine, 'I did confess, but I confessed a lie'
Elizabeth, 'I will prove your innocence'

273-282.description: Justine, trying to comfort Elizabeth with a forced cheerfulness, embraces her and bids her farewell with emotional words, while Elizabeth expresses her wish to die with Justine, unable to bear the world's misery.
text_phrases: Justine assumed an air of cheerfulness
with difficulty repressed her bitter tears
embraced Elizabeth
Farewell, sweet lady, dearest Elizabeth, my beloved and only friend
Elizabeth could tear herself away
I wish that I were to die with you; I cannot live in this world of misery

273-282.description: Victor, overwhelmed by guilt and despair, spends hours on the lake in a boat, contemplating his miserable reflections and the temptation to end his life in the silent waters, yet restrained by thoughts of his loved ones.
text_phrases: I took the boat and passed many hours upon the water
sometimes, with my sails set, I was carried by the wind
gave way to my own miserable reflections
tempted to plunge into the silent lake
the waters might close over me and my calamities for ever

283-290.description: Victor reflects on his creation of the monster and the resulting evils, expressing deep remorse and fear of further atrocities. Meanwhile, his family is engulfed in mourning due to the recent tragic events, deeply affecting Elizabeth and Victor's father.
text_phrases: Our house was the house of mourning
My father’s health was deeply shaken
Elizabeth was sad and desponding
she no longer took delight in her ordinary occupations

283-290.description: Elizabeth discusses the injustice and tragedy of Justine's death, expressing her disillusionment with the world. Victor listens in agony, feeling responsible for the murders indirectly through his creation.
text_phrases: Elizabeth read my anguish in my countenance
kindly taking my hand
banish these dark passions

283-290.description: Victor seeks solace from his overwhelming despair by traveling to the Alpine valleys, reflecting on the unchanging and majestic nature of the mountains compared to his own tormented existence.
text_phrases: I suddenly left my home
bending my steps towards the near Alpine valleys
the magnificence, the eternity of such scenes
the sound of the river raging among the rocks
the dashing of the waterfalls around

291-296.description: The character embarks on a solitary journey up the mountain, surrounded by a desolate yet majestic natural landscape, reflecting on the sublime impact of nature.
text_phrases: ascent is precipitous
path is cut into continual and short windings
traces of the winter avalanche
trees lie broken and strewed on the ground
pines are not tall or luxuriant
valley beneath
vast mists were rising from the rivers
curling in thick wreaths around the opposite mountains
rain poured from the dark sky

291-296.description: The character arrives at the village of Chamounix, exhausted and overwhelmed by the journey, finding solace in the natural sounds and eventually falling asleep.
text_phrases: remained at the window
watching the pallid lightnings
played above Mont Blanc
listening to the rushing of the Arve
head upon my pillow
sleep crept over me

291-296.description: The character spends a day exploring the valley, standing beside the source of the Arveiron and surrounded by the grandeur of nature, which brings consolation and tranquility.
text_phrases: stood beside the sources of the Arveiron
glacier that with slow pace is advancing
abrupt sides of vast mountains
icy wall of the glacier overhung me
shattered pines were scattered around
brawling waves
fall of some vast fragment
thunder sound of the avalanche

297-307.description: The protagonist arrives at the top of a mountain and gazes upon a vast glacier and surrounding peaks. Suddenly, he encounters the creature he created, leading to a dramatic confrontation filled with rage and despair.
text_phrases: sat upon the rock that overlooks the sea of ice
a mist covered both that and the surrounding mountains
breeze dissipated the cloud
surface is very uneven, rising like the waves of a troubled sea
opposite mountain is a bare perpendicular rock
Mont Blanc, in awful majesty
vast river of ice, wound among its dependent mountains
icy and glittering peaks shone in the sunlight over the clouds
figure of a man, at some distance, advancing towards me with superhuman speed
bounded over the crevices in the ice
stature seemed to exceed that of man
rage and horror
countenance bespoke bitter anguish
unearthly ugliness

308-315.description: The protagonist angrily rebukes the creature he created, who in turn asks for compassion and a chance to share his tale. They are on a cold, icy landscape, moving towards a hut on the mountain.
text_phrases: led the way across the ice
ascended the opposite rock
the hut upon the mountain
the sun is yet high in the heavens

308-315.description: Inside the hut, the creature begins to narrate his tale to the protagonist, who listens with a heavy heart by the fire.
text_phrases: entered the hut
seating myself by the fire
he thus began his tale

308-315.description: The creature recounts his earliest memories and sensations, describing his initial experiences with light, darkness, and nature after his creation.
text_phrases: the forest near Ingolstadt
lay by the side of a brook
ate some berries
covered myself with a huge cloak
the bright moon

316-321.description: The character discovers a fire left by wandering beggars in the forest and learns to maintain it.
text_phrases: found a fire which had been left by some wandering beggars
thrust my hand into the live embers
collected some branches
covered it carefully with dry wood and leaves
lay on the ground and sank into sleep

316-321.description: The character discovers a hut in the open country and encounters an old man who flees upon seeing him.
text_phrases: perceived a small hut
old man sat in it, near a fire
devoured the remnants of the shepherd’s breakfast
lay down among some straw and fell asleep

316-321.description: The character arrives at a village, is attacked by the villagers, and escapes to a low hovel.
text_phrases: arrived at a village
children shrieked, and one of the women fainted
escaped to the open country and fearfully took refuge in a low hovel

322-327.description: The protagonist finds a miserable shelter behind a cottage, surrounded by a pig sty and a clear pool of water, and makes it habitable by covering crevices and arranging clean straw inside.
text_phrases: shelter, however miserable
situated against the back of the cottage
surrounded on the sides which were exposed by a pig sty and a clear pool of water
covered every crevice by which I might be perceived with stones and wood
carpeted it with clean straw

all smiled on our nuptial embarkation

658-671.description: Victor and Elizabeth enjoy a scenic boat ride across a lake, observing the surrounding mountains and nature.
text_phrases: We passed rapidly along
sheltered from its rays by a kind of canopy
beauty of the scene
Mont Salêve
Montalègre
Mont Blanc
snowy mountains
Jura opposing its dark side
innumerable fish
swimming in the clear waters
distinguish every pebble

658-671.description: As the sun sets, Victor and Elizabeth experience a change in the weather and land on the shore, feeling a mix of peace and foreboding.
text_phrases: sun sank lower in the heavens
passed the river Drance
Alps here come closer to the lake
spire of Evian shone under the woods
pleasant motion among the trees
delightful scent of flowers and hay
sun sank beneath the horizon
landed
walked for a short time on the shore
retired to the inn

658-671.description: A stormy night sets in, and amidst Victor's fears and preparations, he hears a dreadful scream from Elizabeth, leading to a tragic discovery.
text_phrases: heavy storm of rain descended
night obscured the shapes of objects
right hand grasped a pistol
Elizabeth observed my agitation
walking up and down the passages
shrill and dreadful scream
rushed into the room
lifeless and inanimate
thrown across the bed
her pale and distorted features

672-679.description: The protagonist finds himself in a room with Elizabeth's body, experiencing deep grief and horror as he observes her lifeless form and encounters the monstrous figure at the window.
text_phrases: surrounded by the people of the inn
body of Elizabeth
head upon her arm
handkerchief thrown across her face and neck
pale yellow light of the moon
open window
figure the most hideous and abhorred
fiendish finger
drew a pistol
leaped from his station

672-679.description: After the confrontation, the protagonist and a crowd attempt to track the monster using boats on the lake, but ultimately fail to capture him.
text_phrases: report of the pistol brought a crowd
followed the track with boats
nets were cast
running with the swiftness of lightning
plunged into the lake

672-679.description: Overwhelmed by grief and exhaustion, the protagonist decides to return to Geneva, reflecting on his losses and the drastic changes in his life.
text_phrases: no horses to be procured
return by the lake
hired men to row
took an oar myself
the rain fell in torrents
threw down the oar
leaning my head upon my hands

680-694.description: The protagonist awakens from dreams of pleasant vales to the harsh reality of a dungeon, reflecting on his misery and eventual release.
text_phrases: I lost sensation
chains and darkness were the only objects
I awoke and found myself in a dungeon

680-694.description: The protagonist, after being released, seeks justice by accusing his creation to a magistrate, who is initially incredulous but becomes more attentive.
text_phrases: I repaired to a criminal judge
the magistrate listened to me with attention and kindness
I now related my history briefly but with firmness and precision

680-694.description: The protagonist expresses his rage and disappointment when the magistrate shows reluctance to pursue the monster, leading to a heated exchange.
text_phrases: rage sparkled in my eyes
the magistrate was intimidated
You are mistaken, said he

695-704.description: The protagonist visits the cemetery where his loved ones are buried, and swears vengeance against his enemy.
text_phrases: at the entrance of the cemetery
approached the tomb which marked their graves
leaves of the trees, which were gently agitated by the wind
knelt on the grass

695-704.description: After swearing vengeance, the protagonist hears a fiendish laugh and a voice in the night, confirming his resolve to live and pursue his enemy.
text_phrases: fiendish laugh
loud and fiendish laugh
broad disk of the moon arose and shone full upon his ghastly and distorted shape

695-704.description: The protagonist begins his long pursuit of the fiend, following him across various landscapes and facing numerous hardships.
text_phrases: followed the windings of the Rhone
blue Mediterranean appeared
snows descended on my head
print of his huge step on the white plain

705-712.description: The protagonist experiences joy only in his dreams, where he sees his loved ones and feels their presence vividly.
objects: dream-like ethereal forms of Elizabeth, Clerval, and father
text_phrases: during sleep alone that I could taste joy
I saw my friends, my wife, and my beloved country
benevolent countenance of my father
silver tones of my Elizabeth’s voice
Clerval enjoying health and youth

705-712.description: The protagonist reads a taunting message from the daemon, vowing vengeance and continuing his pursuit through harsh conditions.
text_phrases: he left marks in writing on the barks of the trees
My reign is not yet over
I seek the everlasting ices of the north
you will feel the misery of cold and frost

705-712.description: The protagonist arrives at a hamlet on the seashore, learning that the daemon has just passed through, causing fear and stealing supplies.
text_phrases: a wretched hamlet on the seashore
a gigantic monster
armed with a gun and many pistols
carried off their store of winter food
pursued his journey across the sea

713-722.description: The protagonist exchanges his land-sledge for one suited for the Frozen Ocean, endures hardships, and spots a familiar figure on a distant sledge.
text_phrases: land-sledge for one fashioned for the inequalities of the Frozen Ocean
immense and rugged mountains of ice
the thunder of the ground sea
a dark speck upon the dusky plain
a sledge and the distorted proportions of a well-known form within

713-722.description: The protagonist chases the figure on the sledge, nearly catches up, but is thwarted by a ground sea and left drifting on a piece of ice.
text_phrases: the sledge was still visible
a ground sea was heard
the sea roared
drifting on a scattered piece of ice
tumultuous sea rolled between me and my enemy

713-722.description: The protagonist, on the verge of death, spots a rescue ship, makes a makeshift raft, and is rescued, pleading with the ship's captain to continue his vengeful quest.
713-722.location: Frozen Ocean near a rescue ship
text_phrases: saw your vessel riding at anchor
destroyed part of my sledge to construct oars
moved my ice raft in the direction of your ship
you took me on board

723-730.description: Frankenstein shares his deep reflections and past aspirations with Walton, expressing his profound despair and the weight of his creation.
text_phrases: Frankenstein discovered that I made notes concerning his history
he asked to see them and then himself corrected and augmented them
I have listened to the strangest tale
my thoughts and every feeling of my soul have been drunk up by the interest for my guest
he believes that when in dreams he holds converse with his friends
on every point of general literature he displays unbounded knowledge
his eloquence is forcible and touching

723-730.description: Frankenstein laments his fallen state and the consequences of his ambitious scientific endeavor to Walton, reflecting on his past glory and current misery.
text_phrases: When younger, I believed myself destined for some great enterprise
I possessed a coolness of judgment that fitted me for illustrious achievements
the creation of a sensitive and rational animal
I am chained in an eternal hell
my powers of analysis and application were intense
I trod heaven in my thoughts, now exulting in my powers, now burning with the idea of their effects

723-730.description: Walton expresses his desire to comfort and reconcile Frankenstein to life, despite Frankenstein's deep-seated despair and longing for death.
text_phrases: I wish to soothe him, yet can I counsel one so infinitely miserable
The only joy that he can now know will be when he composes his shattered spirit to peace and death
I thank you, Walton, for your kind intentions towards so miserable a wretch
when you speak of new ties and fresh affections, think you that any can replace those who are gone

731-742.description: The narrator describes the perilous situation of being trapped in ice-covered seas, surrounded by mountains of ice, with his crew looking to him for guidance.
text_phrases: surrounded by mountains of ice
threaten every moment to crush my vessel
brave fellows

731-742.description: A group of sailors confront the narrator in the cabin, demanding a promise to steer the ship southwards if they escape the ice.
text_phrases: half a dozen of the sailors
demanded admission into the cabin
entered
leader addressed me

731-742.description: Frankenstein rouses himself and delivers a passionate speech to the sailors, urging them to be courageous and continue their expedition.
text_phrases: Frankenstein...roused himself
his eyes sparkled
his cheeks flushed
spoke this with a voice so modulated

743-758.description: The scene depicts the final moments of Frankenstein's life as he lies on his deathbed, conversing with Walton about his regrets and final wishes.
text_phrases: sunk in languor and almost deprived of life
he endeavoured to spring from the bed
fell back and fainted
surgeon gave him a composing draught
sat by his bed, watching him
eyes closed
feeble voice
pressed my hand feebly
eyes closed for ever

743-758.description: The crew experiences a moment of peril as the ice around them begins to crack, followed by a moment of joy when the passage towards the south becomes free.
text_phrases: the ice began to move, and roarings like thunder were heard
islands split and cracked in every direction
the ice cracked behind us
a breeze sprang from the west
the passage towards the south became perfectly free
shout of tumultuous joy broke from them

759-769.description: The narrator enters the cabin to find the monstrous creation of Frankenstein mourning over his creator's corpse. The scene is intense and emotional, filled with grief, horror, and a grotesque revelation of the monster's hideous appearance.
text_phrases: cabin where the remains of Frankenstein still lie
gigantic in stature, yet uncouth and distorted in its proportions
his face was concealed by long locks of ragged hair
one vast hand was extended, in colour and apparent texture like that of a mummy
he sprung towards the window

759-769.description: The monster expresses his deep remorse and recounts the agony and misery he endured, which led him to commit his heinous acts. The scene is a dramatic monologue where the monster reveals his inner torment and the consequences of his actions.
text_phrases: That is also my victim!
in his murder my crimes are consummated
the miserable series of my being is wound to its close
I, who irretrievably destroyed thee by destroying all thou lovedst
his voice seemed suffocated

770-775.description: The Creature expresses his deep anguish and plans for his own end while addressing the last human he will ever see.
text_phrases: I shall quit your vessel on the ice raft
He sprang from the cabin-window
upon the ice raft which lay close to the vessel

770-775.description: The Creature leaps from the cabin window onto an ice raft, disappearing into the darkness and distance.
text_phrases: He sprang from the cabin-window
upon the ice raft which lay close to the vessel
He was soon borne away by the waves and lost in darkness and distance
